text: ETHIOPIA IN 2021
label: H1

text: Credits
label: BODY

text: Cover photo: On 10 May 2022 in the internally displaced person (IDP) site of Guyah, Afar Region, Ethiopia, 13-year-old Keria fetches water from a UNICEF
label: BODY

text: Content:
label: BODY

text: Kate Katch, kate.katch@un.org
label: BODY

text: Acting early when the world
label: H2

text: isn’t watching
label: H2

text: Lessons from anticipatory
label: H2

text: action in Ethiopia in 2021
label: H2

text: Highlights
label: BODY

text: For Ethiopia, living with climate volatility requires
label: BODY

text: anticipating droughts and floods and mitigating
label: BODY

text: their impact on the most vulnerable people.
label: BODY

text: In 2020, OCHA facilitated an anticipatory ac-
label: BODY

text: tion framework in Ethiopia to get ahead of
label: BODY

text: droughts and reduce their impact on vulnerable
label: BODY

text: communities.
label: BODY

text: OCHA activated the pilot framework in December
label: BODY

text: 2020, while political and humanitarian focus was
label: BODY

text: on the Tigray conflict in Ethiopia.
label: BODY

text: The Central Emergency Response Fund released
label: BODY

text: US$20 million to reduce the drought’s impact on
label: BODY

text: more than 900,000 people. The allocation was
label: BODY

text: one of the earliest responses to the 2020-2022
label: BODY

text: drought.
label: BODY

text: Three out of five recipients of assistance report-
label: BODY

text: ed an improved ability to afford food, livelihood
label: BODY

text: inputs and household bills.
label: BODY

text: In a world where humanitarian crises compete
label: BODY

text: for political attention and resources, Ethiopia
label: BODY

text: proves that anticipatory action frameworks make
label: BODY

text: acting early the default.
label: BODY

text: The pilot taught valuable lessons in how to im-
label: BODY

text: prove anticipatory action’s impact in the context
label: BODY

text: of protracted and overlapping crises.
label: BODY

text: Seeds ready for distribution at Chereti woreda,Tofik Kebele on 13 June 2021. Credit: FAO/Tewelde
label: BODY

text: Summary
label: HH1

text: 1 Ethiopia survey report by 60 Decibels.
label: BODY

text: When a country is hit by a sudden disaster – an
label: BODY

text: earthquake, a tsunami or floods – the impact is
label: BODY

text: immediate, the crisis makes headlines and aid
label: BODY

text: often follows. But when a country is hit by a slow-
label: BODY

text: moving disaster, such as a drought, it can take
label: BODY

text: months or even years to see the devastating impact.
label: BODY

text: These crises unfold in slow motion: crops fail,
label: BODY

text: livestock die, people sell their assets and leave their
label: BODY

text: homes, women and girls risk their safety as they
label: BODY

text: walk further to find water, and children are pulled
label: BODY

text: from school.
label: BODY

text: Droughts are predictable, but they too often fail to
label: BODY

text: receive funding until suffering reaches catastrophic
label: BODY

text: levels and dramatic images hit the media. This has
label: BODY

text: been Ethiopia’s experience, time and time again.
label: BODY

text: Between October 2020 and June 2022, Ethiopia
label: BODY

text: experienced five consecutive below-average rainy
label: BODY

text: seasons, with the 2022 March-May season being
label: BODY

text: the driest in 70 years. The drought’s prolonged
label: BODY

text: nature ultimately affected an estimated
label: BODY

text: 17 million people.
label: BODY

text: But this time there was a glimmer of hope. The
label: BODY

text: humanitarian community acted earlier thanks to
label: BODY

text: the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitari-
label: BODY

text: an Affairs (OCHA) piloting an anticipatory action
label: BODY

text: framework. In December 2020 – earlier than any
label: BODY

text: other donor – OCHA’s Central Emergency Response
label: BODY

text: Fund (CERF) provided US$20 million to humanitari-
label: BODY

text: an partners to reduce the drought’s impact on more
label: BODY

text: than 900,000 people.
label: BODY

text: According to a satisfaction survey caried out by
label: BODY

text: 60_decibels, more than 60 per cent of the recipients
label: BODY

text: of assistance reported improvements in their
label: BODY

text: overall quality of life.1 The pilot framework also
label: BODY

text: taught valuable lessons in what anticipatory action
label: BODY

text: means in a prolonged and complex crisis. As
label: BODY

text: Joyce Msuya, the Assistant Secretary-General for
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Affairs and Deputy Emergency Relief
label: BODY

text: Coordinator, concluded:
label: BODY

text: “In 2024, drought is once again driving millions of
label: BODY

text: people to suffer. The Ethiopia anticipatory action
label: BODY

text: pilot demonstrated that if we act earlier, people’s
label: BODY

text: lives will be better. We have the evidence, now we
label: BODY

text: must scale.”
label: BODY

text: Firtun Yakob Omar, 21 a mother of 2(L) and her father Yakob Omar Menur, 52 a father of 18 (R) dropping seeds in their farmland supported by FAO in
label: BODY

text: Dolo-Ado woreda, Kelemisge kebele on 12 June 2021. Credit: FAO/Tewelde
label: BODY

text: Challenge
label: HH1

text: 2 IASC, Inter-Agency Humanitarian Evaluation of the Drought Response in Ethiopia (February 2020).
label: BODY

text: Ethiopia is highly vulnerable to severe seasonal
label: BODY

text: droughts; it has experienced them every decade
label: BODY

text: since 1953. They are compounded by conflict,
label: BODY

text: locust invasions, high food prices and localized
label: BODY

text: flooding, meaning communities in Ethiopia continu-
label: BODY

text: ously receive humanitarian aid.
label: BODY

text: Over CERF’s 18-year history, Ethiopia has consist-
label: BODY

text: ently ranked among its top five recipient countries,
label: BODY

text: having received $500 million in CERF funding.
label: BODY

text: Approximately 40 per cent of that funding has gone
label: BODY

text: to drought relief.
label: BODY

text: As Ethiopia is one of the countries most vulner-
label: BODY

text: able to climate change, climate volatility will get
label: BODY

text: worse over the coming years. Positively, advances
label: BODY

text: in weather-and-climate forecasting means there
label: BODY

text: is now more opportunity to limit the humanitarian
label: BODY

text: impact of droughts. However, despite early warning
label: BODY

text: information, the humanitarian community has re-
label: BODY

text: peatedly struggled to act due to a lack of resources
label: BODY

text: and competing global priorities.
label: BODY

text: Following Ethiopia’s 2015-2018 droughts – the
label: BODY

text: worst in 30 years – an inter-agency humanitari-
label: BODY

text: an evaluation found that the response to those
label: BODY

text: droughts saved lives, but it was not timely.2 An
label: BODY

text: earlier response could have stopped people from
label: BODY

text: selling assets to purchase food and pay bills. It
label: BODY

text: could have avoided sharp increases in severe acute
label: BODY

text: malnutrition. Fewer children could have dropped
label: BODY

text: out of school and many illnesses could have
label: BODY

text: been prevented.
label: BODY

text: 18 July 2022. Eli Dar, Afar region. Eli Dar, Afar region. A girl, Fatima, walks with a water container. In eastern Afar, the community at the outskirts of the
label: BODY

text: town of Eli Dar have been experiencing the impact of drought. The grounds that would normally provide a year or more worth of water for the village
label: BODY

text: dried up about 6 months ago and temperatures in the area are into the 40s. Credit: OCHA/Loh-Taylor
label: BODY

text: Solution
label: HH1

text: 3 The IPC Acute Food Insecurity classification differentiates between different levels of severity of acute food insecurity. IPC3+ refers to the crisis
label: BODY

text: phase, characterized by a significant lack of food access, high levels of acute malnutrition, and excess mortality.
label: BODY

text: 4 Ethiopia survey report by 60 Decibels.
label: BODY

text: 5 CERF Anticipatory Action Report 2021.
label: BODY

text: 6 E. Easton-Calabria et al, Anticipatory Action in Complex Crises: Lessons from Ethiopia (December, 2023).
label: BODY

text: 7 E. Easton-Calabria et al, Anticipatory Action in Complex Crises: Lessons from Ethiopia (December, 2023).
label: BODY

text: In 2020, OCHA decided to pilot an anticipatory ac-
label: BODY

text: tion framework in Ethiopia to see how the human-
label: BODY

text: itarian community could get ahead of drought and
label: BODY

text: reduce its impact on vulnerable communities.
label: BODY

text: Anticipatory action frameworks use a model or fore-
label: BODY

text: cast to trigger pre-arranged funding for pre-agreed
label: BODY

text: activities. In essence, a framework pre-determines
label: BODY

text: exactly when funding will be released and who will
label: BODY

text: take what action.
label: BODY

text: In 2020, OCHA’s Centre for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: supported Ethiopia’s humanitarian community
label: BODY

text: to develop a trigger for drought as the basis for
label: BODY

text: the framework. The trigger would be activated
label: BODY

text: if climate forecasts and seasonal risk analysis
label: BODY

text: suggested below-average rainfall during the coming
label: BODY

text: rainy season, and if food security conditions were
label: BODY

text: expected to deteriorate based on projections from
label: BODY

text: the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification.3
label: BODY

text: If the trigger was activated, CERF would provide
label: BODY

text: $20 million to humanitarian partners for a set of
label: BODY

text: predetermined actions.
label: BODY

text: On 28 October 2020, the UN Humanitarian Country
label: BODY

text: Team endorsed the framework. However, just days
label: BODY

text: later, Ethiopia’s Tigray crisis consumed the Govern-
label: BODY

text: ment, the humanitarian community and political
label: BODY

text: attention. Dry conditions in south-east Ethiopia
label: BODY

text: and forecasts of another failed rainy season in
label: BODY

text: early 2021 were overlooked among the noise of the
label: BODY

text: escalating conflict. But they were not overlooked
label: BODY

text: by the humanitarian community. It had resources
label: BODY

text: and an agreed plan to translate early warning into
label: BODY

text: action, thanks to the anticipatory action framework
label: BODY

text: in place.
label: BODY

text: By late November 2020, four regions in Ethiopia
label: BODY

text: met the food insecurity criteria. Almost 13 million
label: BODY

text: people were projected to experience crisis or emer-
label: BODY

text: gency levels of food insecurity within six months
label: BODY

text: (by June 2021). However, not all seasonal climate
label: BODY

text: forecasts met the threshold – some were more
label: BODY

text: certain in predicting a below-average season than
label: BODY

text: others.
label: BODY

text: The forecasts’ uncertainty did not stop a no-regrets
label: BODY

text: approach. To manage the risk of providing funding
label: BODY

text: and a drought not occurring, CERF decided for the
label: BODY

text: first time to split the allocation in two stages. In
label: BODY

text: December 2020, it allocated $13 million to fund
label: BODY

text: activities that required a longer lead time and must
label: BODY

text: happen early, such as preparing land and planting
label: BODY

text: drought-resistant crops. It then released a second
label: BODY

text: allocation of $7 million in February 2021, once the
label: BODY

text: likelihood of below-average rains was confirmed.
label: BODY

text: At a time when Ethiopia had already experienced
label: BODY

text: one failed rainy season, CERF’s funding assisted
label: BODY

text: more than 900,000 people at a critical time, ena-
label: BODY

text: bling communities to make better choices for their
label: BODY

text: families and supporting livelihoods before it was
label: BODY

text: too late. Unlike in previous droughts, almost half of
label: BODY

text: the recipients (44 per cent) reported that the assis-
label: BODY

text: tance came at the right time.4
label: BODY

text: Tens of thousands of households received short-cy-
label: BODY

text: cle/drought-tolerant seeds, livestock packages
label: BODY

text: that included supplemental feeding, treatment and
label: BODY

text: vaccination services, and unconditional cash.5 Re-
label: BODY

text: cipients nearly unanimously agreed the assistance
label: BODY

text: was useful.6
label: BODY

text: As one recipient noted: “My family benefited from
label: BODY

text: the assistance, as we used the money to buy food
label: BODY

text: items. In addition, we spent the money to take care
label: BODY

text: of our children, and the animal feed support was
label: BODY

text: also helpful for our livestock, as there was inade-
label: BODY

text: quate pasture.” Food and Agriculture Organization
label: BODY

text: anticipatory action recipient.7
label: BODY

text: By utilizing existing community-based struc-
label: BODY

text: tures – such as religious institutions, kebele (small
label: BODY

text: administrative unit) leaders, marketplaces, school
label: BODY

text: clubs and local radio stations – almost 250,000
label: BODY

text: community members learned about drought-related
label: BODY

text: protection risks.8
label: BODY

text: More than 80,000 people were able to access safe
label: BODY

text: drinking water through the early rehabilitation of
label: BODY

text: boreholes and non-functioning water schemes
label: BODY

text: and water piping, including in health facilities and
label: BODY

text: schools. A further 25,000 children received water in
label: BODY

text: school during the drought.9
label: BODY

text: Access to clean water meant less disease. As one
label: BODY

text: recipient observed: “The aid improved and secured
label: BODY

text: our family hygiene and health. We’ve been able to
label: BODY

text: prevent communicable diseases.” United Nations
label: BODY

text: Population Fund anticipatory action recipient.10
label: BODY

text: 8 CERF Anticipatory Action Report 2021.
label: BODY

text: 9 CERF Anticipatory Action Report 2021.
label: BODY

text: 10 Ethiopia survey report by 60 Decibels.
label: BODY

text: 11 CERF Anticipatory Action Report 2021.
label: BODY

text: 12 CERF Anticipatory Action Report 2021.
label: BODY

text: To prevent 13,000 children from dropping out of
label: BODY

text: school, almost 3,000 households – mostly female
label: BODY

text: headed – received cash or vouchers to support
label: BODY

text: education costs. A follow-up survey indicated that
label: BODY

text: 100 per cent of the respondents used the cash to
label: BODY

text: buy school materials. In another survey, 90 per cent
label: BODY

text: of the respondents stated the cash helped ensure
label: BODY

text: their children’s continued access to education.11
label: BODY

text: Overall, anticipatory action helped to prevent
label: BODY

text: drought-related suffering. A satisfaction survey
label: BODY

text: conducted by 60_decibels found that three out of
label: BODY

text: five recipients noted an overall improvement in their
label: BODY

text: quality of life due to their increased ability to afford
label: BODY

text: food, livelihood inputs and household bills.12
label: BODY

text: On 10 May 2022 in the internally displaced person (IDP) site of Guyah, Afar Region, Ethiopia, 13-year-old Keria (left) and another girl, fetch water from a
label: BODY

text: UNICEF supported water point. Credit: UNICEF/ Sewunet
label: BODY

text: Takeaway
label: HH1

text: 13 Ethiopia survey report by 60 Decibels.
label: BODY

text: 14 OCHA, Financial Tracking System. Note, the 2021 Ethiopia Humanitarian Response Plan was not exclusive to needs generated by the drought but
label: BODY

text: was a major component. The 2022 Ethiopia Humanitarian Response Plan was in response to the drought and the Tigray crisis.
label: BODY

text: 15 Ethiopia survey report by 60 Decibels.
label: BODY

text: 16 Ethiopia survey report by 60 Decibels.
label: BODY

text: For Ethiopia, living with climate volatility will require
label: BODY

text: anticipating droughts and floods, and mitigating
label: BODY

text: their impact on the most vulnerable people. Ulti-
label: BODY

text: mately, more climate adaptation is required, but the
label: BODY

text: humanitarian community also has an important
label: BODY

text: role to play. The pilot in Ethiopia demonstrates that
label: BODY

text: anticipatory action holds promise.
label: BODY

text: In a world where humanitarian crises compete for
label: BODY

text: political attention and resources, Ethiopia illustrates
label: BODY

text: that anticipatory action frameworks make acting
label: BODY

text: early the default.
label: BODY

text: Catherine Sozi, the former UN Resident and Human-
label: BODY

text: itarian Coordinator for Ethiopia, explained: “In late
label: BODY

text: 2020 and 2021, media headlines, political atten-
label: BODY

text: tion and resources were focused on the COVID-19
label: BODY

text: pandemic, the Tigray crisis in Ethiopia, a military
label: BODY

text: coup in Myanmar, the Taliban takeover in Afghani-
label: BODY

text: stan and a large-scale earthquake in Haiti. No one
label: BODY

text: was paying attention to failed rains in Ethiopia. The
label: BODY

text: anticipatory action framework meant we could act
label: BODY

text: when it would make a difference to communities.
label: BODY

text: We didn’t need to wait for people to suffer and the
label: BODY

text: drought to make the headlines.”
label: BODY

text: The pilot also revealed valuable lessons about
label: BODY

text: anticipatory action’s place in the context of pro-
label: BODY

text: tracted and overlapping crises and an underfunded
label: BODY

text: response.
label: BODY

text: Anticipatory action is intended to mitigate the im-
label: BODY

text: pact of one shock, such as drought. CERF funding
label: BODY

text: came after the first failed rains (October-December
label: BODY

text: 2020), but households had to endure five consec-
label: BODY

text: utive below-average rainy seasons (October 2020
label: BODY

text: to June 2022).13 Communities also had to live with
label: BODY

text: drought alongside other crises, such as conflict,
label: BODY

text: localized flooding, a locust invasion and inflation.
label: BODY

text: It’s also important to consider the scale of antic-
label: BODY

text: ipatory action compared to the size of the need.
label: BODY

text: CERF’s $20 million grant was approximately 1 per
label: BODY

text: cent of the overall requirements of the Humanitar-
label: BODY

text: ian Response Plan in 2021, and funding require-
label: BODY

text: ments for the 2020-2022 drought response were
label: BODY

text: only half met.14 It is therefore understandable that
label: BODY

text: 49 per cent of the recipients interviewed in 2022
label: BODY

text: said the anticipatory action assistance hardly met
label: BODY

text: or met none of their drought-related needs.15
label: BODY

text: As Lisa Doughten, Director of OCHA’s Financing and
label: BODY

text: Partnerships Division, noted: “CERF funding contin-
label: BODY

text: ues to be an indispensable enabler for anticipatory
label: BODY

text: action, but to truly scale up its impact, more flexible
label: BODY

text: and coordinated financing is needed.”
label: BODY

text: In addition to exposing the impact of funding
label: BODY

text: constraints, the pilot also yielded lessons in how to
label: BODY

text: increase the impact of anticipatory action.
label: BODY

text: Julia Wittig, Anticipatory Action Lead for CERF,
label: BODY

text: explained: “The pilot helped us to further refine the
label: BODY

text: type of activities and the timing of those interven-
label: BODY

text: tions. For example, some activities, such as prepar-
label: BODY

text: ing land and distributing seed, must happen early
label: BODY

text: and require a longer lead time. But they are critical
label: BODY

text: to food consumption and preventing negative cop-
label: BODY

text: ing strategies later. The decision to split the CERF
label: BODY

text: allocation allowed us to time interventions for when
label: BODY

text: they make the difference, while mitigating the risks
label: BODY

text: of releasing funding before a drought is certain.”
label: BODY

text: Improving collective targeting can also help to
label: BODY

text: maximize impact. Humanitarian partners jointly
label: BODY

text: identified districts for assistance, but aid was often
label: BODY

text: distributed to different households with different
label: BODY

text: packages of support. The 60_decibels survey
label: BODY

text: illustrated a more granular approach, where human-
label: BODY

text: itarian partners identify the most vulnerable house-
label: BODY

text: holds to assist with an intersectoral package of
label: BODY

text: support. This could have led to better outcomes for
label: BODY

text: those families.16 OCHA and humanitarian partners
label: BODY

text: are pursuing collective targeting for anticipatory
label: BODY

text: action frameworks in Bangladesh, Burkina Faso,
label: BODY

text: Chad and Niger.
label: BODY

text: Ethiopia also helped to improve future anticipatory
label: BODY

text: action triggers for droughts. Ethiopia shows that
label: BODY

text: food security assessments are crucial to determine
label: BODY

text: the population’s vulnerability and where to prior-
label: BODY

text: itize aid. However, the assessments require some
label: BODY

text: improvements to serve as a trigger for anticipatory
label: BODY

text: action.
label: BODY

text: Willem Muhren, Head of OCHA’s Information Man-
label: BODY

text: agement Unit in Ethiopia, said: “Food security as-
label: BODY

text: sessments are published after the rainy season so
label: BODY

text: they can estimate what will happen with the food
label: BODY

text: security situation. This is too late, for example, if we
label: BODY

text: want to plant drought-resistant seeds. We need to
label: BODY

text: get ahead of the shock, not just respond earlier.”
label: BODY

text: Since the pilot in Ethiopia, OCHA is focusing on
label: BODY

text: climate indicators for drought-related anticipatory
label: BODY

text: action frameworks in Burkina Faso, the Central
label: BODY

text: American Dry Corridor, Chad and Niger.
label: BODY

text: Overall, the pilot successfully mitigated some of the
label: BODY

text: drought’s impact on vulnerable households. Impor-
label: BODY

text: tantly, it proved that anticipatory action works, gen-
label: BODY

text: erating momentum in the humanitarian community
label: BODY

text: to get ahead of climate shocks. OCHA will update
label: BODY

text: and renew Ethiopia’s anticipatory action framework
label: BODY

text: in 2024, with CERF pre-committing $15 million.
label: BODY

text: Given the drought pilot’s success, and recognizing
label: BODY

text: the multiple risks Ethiopia faces, a new collective
label: BODY

text: anticipatory action framework for floods will be
label: BODY

text: explored. This is part of OCHA’s portfolio of pre-ar-
label: BODY

text: ranged funding of more than $100 million in 15
label: BODY

text: countries for storms, floods, droughts and cholera.
label: BODY

text: As Ethiopia confronts another drought in 2024,
label: BODY

text: more flexible funding for anticipatory action is
label: BODY

text: needed. As Ms. Msuya concluded: “now is the time
label: BODY

text: to scale.”
label: BODY

text: On 12 May 2022 at a UNICEF MY Home/Bete school Dubti, Afar Region, Ethiopia, Ibrahim Ali (left) attends a class designed to provide a safe space for
label: BODY

text: boys and girls living amid humanitarian emergencies by integrating accelerated learning, child protection and skills development. Credit: UNICEF
label: BODY
